title: Wisdom and Integrity
shortSummary: Proverbs 19 offers practical wisdom on integrity, the consequences of folly, and the value of discipline and understanding. It contrasts the righteous and the foolish, emphasizing the blessings of fearing the LORD and living wisely. This chapter encourages believers to pursue godly wisdom for a life marked by righteousness and peace.

keyCharacters.name: The Fool
keyCharacters.description: A person characterized by folly, lack of understanding, and perverse speech, whose actions lead to ruin and shame.

keyCharacters.name: The Wise Man
keyCharacters.description: One who seeks wisdom and understanding, loves his soul, and finds good through discretion and instruction.

keyCharacters.name: The Poor Man
keyCharacters.description: A person of low economic status who may be despised or isolated but is valued when walking in integrity.

keyCharacters.name: The King
keyCharacters.description: A figure of authority whose wrath is powerful like a roaring lion, but whose favor is refreshing like dew.

definitions.definition: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles; uprightness.
One who mocks or shows contempt for others, especially for godly instruction.
The ability to make wise decisions and to control one's anger or impulses.
A person who lies or gives untrue testimony, especially in a legal or moral context.
A reverential awe and respect for God that leads to obedience and life.

outline.heading: The Value of Integrity and Wisdom
outline.description: This section contrasts the poor man who walks in integrity with the fool who speaks perversely, highlighting the importance of knowledge, wisdom, and understanding for a good life.

outline.heading: Consequences of Folly and the Power of Discretion
outline.description: Warnings against false witness and folly are given alongside the benefits of discretion, patience, and prudent relationships, including the influence of a king’s wrath and favor.

outline.heading: Family and Social Relationships
outline.description: This section addresses the importance of obedience to commandments, discipline of children, and the shame brought by rebellious behavior within the family.

outline.heading: The Sovereignty of God’s Counsel and the Fear of the LORD
outline.description: The chapter concludes by affirming that human plans are subject to God’s counsel, emphasizing the blessing of fearing the LORD and the judgment prepared for scoffers and fools.

application: Pursue integrity and wisdom daily, valuing godly knowledge over worldly wealth or status.
Practice patience and discretion to maintain peace and avoid unnecessary anger or conflict.
Discipline children with loving correction while there is hope, trusting in God’s guidance.
Fear the LORD sincerely, knowing it leads to life, satisfaction, and protection from evil.

keyVerses.text: Better is the poor that walketh in his integrity, than he that is perverse in his lips, and is a fool.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the supreme value of integrity over wealth or clever speech.

keyVerses.text: The discretion of a man deferreth his anger; and it is his glory to pass over a transgression.
keyVerses.significance: It teaches the wisdom of controlling anger and forgiving offenses as a mark of true honor.

keyVerses.text: He that hath pity upon the poor lendeth unto the LORD; and that which he hath given will he pay him again.
keyVerses.significance: This verse encourages generosity, assuring that God rewards those who help the needy.

keyVerses.text: The fear of the LORD tendeth to life: and he that hath it shall abide satisfied; he shall not be visited with evil.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes that reverence for God leads to a fulfilling and protected life.
